key_points: The Ever Given cargo ship got stuck in the Suez Canal, severely impacting global supply chains.
The mishap began with difficulty maneuvering due to aggressive rudder commands and strong winds, eventually leading the ship to lodge itself between both banks.
Marine engineer Julianne Cona photographed the incident, which went viral on social media.
The Egyptian government initially blamed the ship's engine failure and then the captain's high speed, despite control over speed being in the hands of the Suez Canal pilots.
Egypt demanded $916.5 million in damages from the ship's owners, a claim met with skepticism from maritime legal experts.
Investigation into the mishap brought attention to the training and handling challenges of large ships in narrow canals.
Port Revel's simulation demonstrated the impact of speed on ship control and the effectiveness of tugboats in managing navigation under strong winds.
The Ever Given crew were stranded for an extended period, facing uncertainty and the possibility of charges, while negotiations over compensation dragged on.
Negotiations concluded with Egypt reducing its demand to $550 million, and an undisclosed settlement was reached after three months.
The incident highlighted the need for better handling techniques in canals and the complexities of maritime legal disputes.
spokespersons: Abdulgani Serang (General Secretary, National Union of Seafarers of India)
Martin Davies (Head, Tulane University's Maritime Law Center)
